perturbation.original_text: RIGHTS GRANTED   Licensor grants to Rogers the non-exclusive license and right to distribute and exhibit in Canada (the "Territory") all entertainment programming to which Licensor owns or controls the VOD distribution and exhibition rights in the Territory (collectively, "Licensed Programs") to residential subscribers of Rogers' digital cable television service on a Video-on-Demand ("VOD") basis. For clarity, the VOD service that Rogers provides to such subscribers shall hereinafter be referred to as the "ROD Service".
perturbation.changed_text: RIGHTS GRANTED   Licensor grants to Rogers the exclusive license and right to distribute and exhibit in Canada (the "Territory") all entertainment programming to which Licensor owns or controls the VOD distribution and exhibition rights in the Territory (collectively, "Licensed Programs") to residential subscribers of Rogers' digital cable television service on a Video-on-Demand ("VOD") basis. For clarity, the VOD service that Rogers provides to such subscribers shall hereinafter be referred to as the "ROD Service".
perturbation.explanation: Changing "non-exclusive license" to "exclusive license" creates a conflict. The contract later refers to Licensor's agreements with other parties. If Licensor enters or has entered into agreements with third parties, this implies a non-exclusive arrangement. In Canada, exclusivity in distribution rights has specific legal implications under competition law and contract law, which are now contradicted.

perturbation.original_text: Rogers shall pay to Licensor a fee (the "License Fee"), which shall be equal to fifty (50)% of Retail Revenues.   For the purposes of this Agreement, "Retail Revenues" means the retail revenues actually received by Rogers for each authorized exhibition of a Licensed Program on the ROD Service, less GST and applicable sales tax. For greater certainty, Retail Revenues shall not include any fees payable to Rogers for: (i) the purchase, rental or installation of a digital terminal; (ii) any basic or premium television services; or (iii) digital cable access.
perturbation.changed_text: Rogers shall pay to Licensor a fee (the "License Fee"), which shall be equal to fifty (50)% of Retail Revenues.   For the purposes of this Agreement, "Retail Revenues" means the retail revenues deemed appropriate by Rogers for each exhibition of a Licensed Program on the ROD Service, without deductions. For greater certainty, Retail Revenues shall include any fees payable to Rogers for: (i) the purchase, rental or installation of a digital terminal; (ii) any basic or premium television services; or (iii) digital cable access.
perturbation.explanation: Altering the definition of 'Retail Revenues' to mean 'revenues deemed appropriate by Rogers' and removing deductions gives Rogers the ability to arbitrarily determine the revenue amount. The addition of terminal and access fees to the revenue definition also conflicts with standard accounting practices and creates uncertainty in calculating royalties, which affects enforceability under Canadian contract law.

perturbation.original_text: Any notice, request, demand, consent or other communication (collectively a "Notice") provided or permitted hereunder shall be in writing and given by personal delivery (against receipt), or sent by registered mail (against receipt) postage prepaid, or transmitted by facsimile (provided that a hard copy is immediately sent by registered mail), addressed to the other party for which it is intended at its address below:
perturbation.changed_text: Any notice, request, demand, consent or other communication (collectively a "Notice") provided or permitted hereunder shall be considered sufficiently delivered if sent electronically. The parties consent to use electronic signatures. Rogers may change its designated e-mail at any time. No hard copy is required.
perturbation.explanation: Canada's laws regarding contract notices and electronic signatures require specific compliance measures (e.g., the Electronic Commerce Act) to ensure validity and enforceability. This change creates a conflict. It removes the requirement for hard copies of faxed notices and allows Rogers to change its contact information without proper notice. The change introduces ambiguity, especially if there is no guarantee of receipt.
